title: Liberal group releases Supreme Court short list for next Democratic president
text:
A liberal advocacy group released a short list Tuesday of potential judicial nominees for the next Democratic president to use as a guide for selecting justices to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court should one arise.

The organization led by Brian Fallon, who previously served as Hillary Clinton’s press secretary, listed 32 legal scholars his group would like to see elevated to the federal bench.

Several law professors and attorneys from progressive advocacy groups are on this list, as well as some circuit court judges and justices from the California Supreme Court.

Xavier Becerra, the attorney general of California who has led several coalitions of blue states suing the Trump administration to stop a number of policies related to immigration, is also on the list.

“Democrats running for president should tell primary voters who they might appoint to the Supreme Court. And they should be bold enough to pick someone who’s worked to defend civil rights, worker’s rights or reproductive rights,” tweeted Mr. Fallon, executive director of Demand Justice.

Demand Justice, in a statement, noted none of the individuals it’s promoting are corporate lawyers.

Carrie Severino, chief counsel of the conservative Judicial Crisis Network that backs President Trump’s judicial nominees, slammed the liberal group’s list.

“These people are radicals. This list is a dream come true for far-left activists who seek to turn the courts into a political super-legislature,” Ms. Severino said.

In its statement touting the list, Demand Justice noted the success Mr. Trump had during his 2016 campaign in releasing a short-list of judicial nominees he would use to fill high court vacancies. The group wants the 2020 Democratic presidential nominee to emulate Mr. Trump’s past strategy.

“Doing so would show their commitment to the Supreme Court as an issue and draw a clear line in the sand about what is at stake in the coming election,” the group’s statement read.

Thus far, none of the 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have provided a list of names they’e considering for federal bench appointments.

But Sen. Elizabeth Warren, Sen. Kamala Harris, and South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg have all suggested they are open to expanding the number of justices on the high court to counterbalance the conservative 5-4 majority on the court.

That idea was dismissed by liberal-icon Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in July, who told NPR court packing would make the tribunal look “partisan.”

“Nine seems to be a good number. It’s been that way for a long time,” Justice Ginsburg said.

SCOTUSBlog, a private website created by Washington attorney Tom Goldstein that tracks the Supreme Court, described Demand Justice’s list as diverse, and added it’s an ideal guide for progressives.

“Ideologically, the list is a liberal parallel to the conservative list used by President Trump. The critical difference is that progressives have far less influence in Democratic SCOTUS appointments than conservatives have in Republican appointments,” SCOTUSBlog tweeted.

In a 2016 exit poll conducted by CNN, 56 percent of voters that backed Mr. Trump said Supreme Court appointments were the “most important” factor in their vote. Only 41 percent of those who backed Mrs. Clinton said the same.
